definition: to make a story or theory consistent/to give a plausible explanation/to plug the holes in one's story
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
circle/round/circular/spherical/(of the moon) full/unit of Chinese currency (yuan)/tactful/to make consistent and whole (the narrative of a dream or a lie)
his/her/its/their/that/such/it (refers to sth preceding it)
to persuade
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)
variant of 說|说[shuo1]

sentences.english: Rowling will have to think up something clever for this one.
sentences.chinese: 罗琳必须想一个高明的籍口才能自圆其说。

sentences.english: Does he have a way out of it?
Otherwise if, hard to avoid has justify oneself , the ill will of exaggerated absurd argument.
sentences.chinese: 否则的话，难免有自圆其说，夸大奇谈之嫌。
这些模型在理论上能够自圆其说。

sentences.english: Some are apparently hiding in plain sight.
sentences.chinese: 一些报道显然是在自圆其说。

definition: to contradict oneself/self-contradictory/inconsistent
specious arguments/sophistry
to refute/to demolish (an argument, theory etc)
(of an argument, theory etc) full of flaws (idiom)
to patch up one's lie (when inconsistencies appear)/to cover (for sb who has lied)
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
convincing
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
(of an argument, theory etc) full of flaws (idiom)
lit. to quote the classics/to quote chapter and verse (idiom)
to twist words and force logic (idiom)/sophistry/loud rhetoric making up for fallacious argument/shoving false arguments down people's throats
apparently right but actually wrong; specious (idiom)
to dispute/to refute
far-fetched/implausible (chain of reasoning)
circular argument/logical error consisting of begging the question/Latin: petitio principii
to make things up/to concoct (a story, an excuse etc)
